messages.text: javascript

lua could have been such a great scripting language, but they had to go and handle `nil` and "falsiness" in a laughably absurd way...
```Lua 5.4.0  Copyright (C) 1994-2020 <http://Lua.org|Lua.org>, PUC-Rio
> a
nil
> if not a then print("fuck") end
fuck
> v = {1.0, 2.0}
> v[3]
nil
> if not (v[5] == 5.0) then print("fuck") end
fuck```
:scream:

messages.text: Last I heard Lua was practically dead after 5.{1,2,3,...?} all introduced breaking API changes. LuaJIT also had enough and stopped after 5.1, so libraries need to support something like 3-4 versions, each with a different API.

messages.text:
One gripe though is that Blosc.jl doesn't work on SubArrays.

```julia> Blosc.compress(@view A[1:1024])
ERROR: MethodError: no method matching compress(::SubArray{UInt8,1,Array{UInt8,1},Tuple{UnitRange{Int64}},true})
Closest candidates are:
  compress(::Ptr{T}, ::Integer; kws...) where T at C:\Users\kittisopikulm\.julia\dev\Blosc\src\Blosc.jl:105
  compress(::DenseArray; kws...) at C:\Users\kittisopikulm\.julia\dev\Blosc\src\Blosc.jl:111
  compress(::AbstractString; kws...) at C:\Users\kittisopikulm\.julia\dev\Blosc\src\Blosc.jl:115
Stacktrace:
 [1] top-level scope at REPL[151]:1```

attachments.fallback:
[March 19th, 2021 8:50 PM] markkitt: I have new appreciation for how easy Blosc.jl is to use.

Today someone asked me for help with python-blosc. For `a` a NumPy array, the most efficient compression call apparently looks like this:
```blosc.compress_ptr(a.__array_interface__['data'][0], a.size, a.dtype.itemsize, 9,cname= 'lz4')```
I think numcodecs is probably easier to use, but this was a bit shocking.
attachments.text:
I have new appreciation for how easy Blosc.jl is to use.

Today someone asked me for help with python-blosc. For `a` a NumPy array, the most efficient compression call apparently looks like this:
```blosc.compress_ptr(a.__array_interface__['data'][0], a.size, a.dtype.itemsize, 9,cname= 'lz4')```
I think numcodecs is probably easier to use, but this was a bit shocking.

messages.text:
Not from me. Via hackernews

<https://github.com/JuliaOptics/About>
```This organization and its repositories have been abandoned.  The About section below is left intact.  The work was abandoned for the following reasons:

* Julia does not offer significant acceleration over the numpy code of [prysm](<https://github.com/brandondube/prysm>) -- only about 20%
* writing performant julia is significantly more difficult than writing performant numpy.  The base language emits unvectorized code which is slower than numpy, the `@avx` macro is unstable and often crashes the interpreter, the allocator is much slower than numpy or even matlab, and `.` and `!` are quasi-white space symbols that are far too important to the performance of an algorithm.  `@.` prefixes to a line are slower than hand placing the `.`, so that is not a solution
* the language itself, as well as its tooling, is too immature, with poor documentation and many bugs or sharp edges
* errors in Julia are severely cluttered by multiple line long type information which does not aid clarity```

elements.text:
This organization and its repositories have been abandoned.  The About section below is left intact.  The work was abandoned for the following reasons:

* Julia does not offer significant acceleration over the numpy code of [prysm](

) -- only about 20%
* writing performant julia is significantly more difficult than writing performant numpy.  The base language emits unvectorized code which is slower than numpy, the `@avx` macro is unstable and often crashes the interpreter, the allocator is much slower than numpy or even matlab, and `.` and `!` are quasi-white space symbols that are far too important to the performance of an algorithm.  `@.` prefixes to a line are slower than hand placing the `.`, so that is not a solution
* the language itself, as well as its tooling, is too immature, with poor documentation and many bugs or sharp edges
* errors in Julia are severely cluttered by multiple line long type information which does not aid clarity

3```

messages.text:
I just figured out how to do this with Julia which I am quite pleased about using Plots.jl! However, the code to make a title appear and have a colorbar appear is a pain to have figured out as it is not documented clearly anywhere or very nice to write. I wish that it could be something like `plot(x, data, title = "My Pretty Plot", fill_z = [RGB Color types]` and done. In the thread is the code I used to answer my own question from discourse here: <https://discourse.julialang.org/t/how-do-i-add-a-colorbar-to-a-choropleth-map/57814>

P.S. This was my first gripe here so sorry if I was too complainy! :grimacing:

Am I the only one who always have troubles after updating Julia versions? Like no matter what I do, which guide I read, whether I use Atom or VSCode, something goes wrong? Since Julia 0.7 I don't think I've had one smooth upgrade (so clearly this is 99% on me)

Newest iteration:
```Pkg.instantiate()
ERROR: AssertionError: sourcepath !== nothing```
while running the file in 1.5.0 that worked one hour ago...

On the bright side: time to first plot down from 9 to 5 seconds on my machine - nice! :+1:

messages.text: No 'as fast as a loop'  `yield` statements in Julia base.

messages.text:
I legit just got burned by python's cryptography package requiring a rust toolchain.

I was trying to help a friend do some work on a computer his company gave him with an old cpu, and the version of the package we needed required a version of cryptography which was too new-- rust didn't support the architecture.

messages.text:
Why isn't `filter` defined for `AbstractArray` like `map` is?
```julia> d = Dict(:a => 1, :b => 2, :c => 3);

julia> map(x -> x > 1, values(d))
3-element Vector{Bool}:
 0
 1
 1

julia> filter(x -> x > 1, values(d))
ERROR: MethodError: no method matching filter(::var"#1#2", ::Base.ValueIterator{Dict{Symbol, Int64}})```

elements.text:

 1
 1

messages.text: That things like whether a space is shown after commas in lists of say dicts and type parameters are changed between Julia versions (Julia 1.6 added them after commas). Either choice to me seems perfectly fine and I generally don't care, but by changing it between versions it now broke about a gazillion doc tests in the packages I maintain, _and_ now I can't have doc tests that work on all the Julia versions that the package supports. Those kind of small changes might look like an improvement in isolation, but often IMHO just the fact that this can cause a lot of churn downstream might make such cosmetic changes not worth it.
